title: 108_hr3282
content:
The "Healthy America Commission Act of 2003" establishes the "Healthy America Commission" with specified duties. The Commission will study and report on the societal costs of preventable diseases in the US, including the Federal Government's share, impact on healthcare quality, costs and savings of prevention programs, and incentives for behavioral changes. The Commission will study cost-benefit ratios for disease prevention initiatives, target goals for progress measurement, monitoring procedures, pilot demonstration programs, and the efficiency of existing prevention programs. SEC. 4. MEMBERSHIP. The Commission consists of 11 members appointed by the President in consultation with congressional leaders. Each member serves for the life of the Commission, vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. Members are paid at a rate equal to the minimum annual rate of basic pay for level IV of the Executive Schedule. The Commission consists of 11 members appointed by the President in consultation with congressional leaders. Each member serves for the life of the Commission and receives travel expenses according to applicable provisions. The President designates the Chairperson from among the members, and the Commission may procure services of experts and consultants as needed. Meetings are held at the call of the Chairperson or a majority of members. The Commission has powers as outlined in Section 5. The Commission, under Section 5, has the authority to hold hearings, take testimony, receive evidence, and use the United States mails. Members and agents can take actions authorized by the Commission, and federal agencies can provide personnel support upon request. The Commission can request administrative support services from the Administrator of General Services on a reimbursable basis. It can also accept gifts, bequests, and devises to aid its work, with funds deposited in the Treasury for disbursement upon the Commission's order. SEC. 6. REPORTS.

(a) Interim Report.--Within 12 months of enactment, the Commission must submit an interim report to Congress, the President, and the Secretary of Health and Human Services.

(b) Final Report.--Within 2 years of enactment, the Commission must submit a final report to Congress, the President, and the Secretary of Health and Human Services containing findings, conclusions, and recommendations.

SEC. 7. TERMINATION.

The Commission will end 90 days after submitting its final report.

SEC. 8. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Authorization of Appropriations: $7,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2005 through 2007 to carry out this Act.
